Reed switches were long used in some aircraft to verify internal locking of hydraulic actuators.  Encapsulated switches were installed in removable rod ends screwed into actuator rams.  When the ram was fully retracted, a mechanical lock would drop into place to prevent uncommanded actuator extension.  The lock included a magnet that would open the reed switch.  A failure to lock would complete a circuit to an indicator module in the cockpit and signal that the actuator was not locked.  Although reasonably reliable, most reed switches have now been replaced by more sophisticated proximity sensors.
